newsitem.title: USA: US greens propose import sugar fees for Everglades.
newsitem.headline: US greens propose import sugar fees for Everglades.

text.p: The National Audubon Society asked the Clinton Administration on Thursday to hold an annual sugar import auction to raise an estimated $100 million to help pay for restoration of the fragile Florida Everglades.

"It makes sense to link Everglades restoration to the federal sugar program," said John Flicker, president of the National Audubon Society. "The sugar program helped create the problems we face in the Everglades."

Under the proposal, over 500,000 tons of raw sugar imported into the nation each year -- above the 1.25 million ton GATT minimum -- would be sold at auction, Flicker said. Similar import auctions are in place in New Zealand, Australia and Colombia.
The proposal would require President Clinton to sign an executive order directing the Agriculture Department to conduct the auction.
Environmentalists, sugar producers and other industry groups have battled for years over how to pay for billions of dollars needed to clean up the Everglades.
